Description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission announced that Home Depot U.S.A. Inc. agreed to pay a $5.7 million civil penalty for selling and distributing previously recalled consumer products. The agreement settled allegations that the firm knowingly sold and distributed approximately 2,816 recalled products from 33 separate voluntary corrective actions during a four-year period from August 2012 through November 2016.
Info Source: https://www.cpsc.gov/Newsroom/News-Releases/2017/Home-Depot-Agrees-to-Pay-5_7-Million-Civil-Penalty-Maintain-Compliance-Program-for-Selling-and-Distributing-Recalled-Products

Description: HD Supply Waterworks--the nation's largest supplier of water, sewer, fire protection and storm drain products--agreed to pay the United States $4,945,000 under the False Claims Act to resolve allegations that it participated in a scheme designed to take advantage of the Disadvantaged Business Enterprise program in order to obtain subcontracts on federally-funded projects.
Agency: U.S. Attorney-Northern District of New York
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/usao-ndny/pr/hd-supply-waterworks-pay-nearly-5-million-resolve-grant-fraud-allegations

Description: Home Depot and the new owner of its banking partner GE Capital Corp. agreed to pay the state and customers a total of $672,000 in settlement of allegations it paid off interest free credit card debt from special offers before paying off normal debt, unfairly increasing customers' interest costs. The announcement did not indicate how much each company would pay. Here we assume they split the total equally.
Info Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20091021051746/http://www.ct.gov/ag/cwp/view.asp?A=2426&Q=313314

Description: Home Depot agreed to pay a civil penalty of $99,000 and $326,000 for supplemental environmental projects in settlement of allegations it violated environmental regulations with improper display, handling and disposal of products containing hazardous materials such as pesticides and fertilizers.
Agency: Connecticut Department of Energy & Environmental Protection

Description: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and the Department of Justice announced a nationwide settlement with Home Depot U.S.A. Inc. resolving alleged violations of the EPA's Lead Renovation, Repair and Painting (RRP) Rule at home renovations performed by Home Depot' contractors across the country.  The States of Utah, Massachusetts, and Rhode Island, which have EPA-authorized RRP programs, joined the United States in this action.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department
Info Source: https://www.epa.gov/enforcement/home-depot-settlement-information-sheet
